heading: rants & raves
subheading: date: thu, 30 dec 1999 10:28:18 -0600 from: “mark thornton” (mark@corridor.net) to: newsfeedback@wired.com subject: etoy vs. etoys issue why haven’t you been questioning why network solutions allowed etoy.com to be attacked when it clearly had been in existence and had all legal rights to the name (“etoy: ‘the fight isn’t over’,” 30.dec.99)? why are we […]
author: wired blogs
text: date: thu, 30 dec 1999 10:28:18 -0600 from: "mark thornton" (mark@corridor.net)to: newsfeedback@wired.comsubject: etoy vs. etoys issuewhy haven't you been questioning why network solutions allowed etoy.com to be attacked when it clearly had been in existence and had all legal rights to the name ("etoy: 'the fight isn't over'," 30.dec.99)? why are we all assuming the network solutions has no responsibility to uphold and defend their own policies? if someone at network solutions would have said no to etoys.com earlier in the process the appropriate legal questions could have been resolved without the current level of foolishness.we have all come to believe that network solutions has no responsibility to maintain the integrity and reliability of the domain space, and it is obvious that icann is incapable of doing so. unless these larger issues are raised and answered this sort of thing will happen again and again. it is my opinion that etoy needs to find a judge that will issuea restraining order on etoys.com for copyright infringement and shut down their domain name. then we would get to the real heart of the issue, "what's in a name".
